Topic.Title: CSCO Tech bellwether is up big time

Message.Msg: Since Cisco is considered a bell-weather stock due to its large global presence and they have come out with good results and decent forecasts, I suspect that the Q3 sales drop-off was mostly due to customers pushing out purchases for Windows 8.

Topic.Title: SANTELLI !!! you are a people person

Message.Msg: Rick's jammed up today with meetings so he asked me to get back to you on his behalf. The point is that interest rates and equity values used to be determined by buyers and sellers through booms and busts until 9/11. Then Greenspan kept rates low for years and produced the real estate bubble of 2005 - 2007. Now the Fed is buying $40 bil of mortgage securities per month because there is no longer a secondary mortgage market in this country as existed in the late '70's through 2002 which allowed the baby boomers to buy houses. The point is that by leveraging up the Treasury & Fed have absorbed some of the effects of Americans deleveraging after the bubble burst in 2008. But at some point US debt is going to turn down because of the sheer amount of it. Rick wants to take the hit sooner rather than later because the deficit is growing currently at $120 bil per month. The cliff is growing $4 bil per day even though for the last 19 quarters since Q1 2008 consumer spending has only grown an average of .7% per Q while it averaged an increase of 3.6% per Q in the 10 years from 1998 thru 2007. So Rick wants to take the hit now at about $16.5 trillion of debt instead of taking it at $20 trillion. Rick thinks the dive off a $20 trillion cliff will be fatal. He also things income tax alone won't get it done. A wealth tax is another option. I hope this helps.

Message.Title: Correction?
Message.Msg: How long will this correction last? Is this the beginning of a new bear market (20% decline or more)? Nobody has the answers.... This bull market is nearly four years old, and may be too tired to begin a new uptrend? If you are a trader, then raising cash has already been done. If you are a long term investor, then you may be looking for an entry point? IBM has pierced all technical levels in heavy volume, and is now in a free fall. There is no way of knowing when/where it will bottom. I am just observing the markets knowing that the correction/bear market will bring better prices to buy quality stocks like IBM.
